entry.title: Subscription Failed While Subscribing to Integration suite in BTP Trail account
entry.content:
Hello SAP experts,

i am currently trying to subscribe to the integration suite in my  SAP BTP Trail account, but i keep getting the following error:

i have already checked entitlements and integration suite is assigned to the subaccount .

Could some one guide me on :

What could be the causing this error?

is there a limitation or known issue wth BTP Trail accounts for integration suite ?

any steps to resolve this ?

thanks in advance for your help

entry.title: Build Workflow with SAP Build Process Automation: A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

In this blog, we’ll walk through the steps to create your very first process using SAP Build Process Automation (SBPA). We’ll implement an Vendor Invoice Validation and Approval Process, where a Finance Clerk submits a vendor invoice, and a Finance Manager approves or rejects it. You'll also learn how to set up your environment in a SAP BTP trial account, configure prerequisites, and monitor your workflow execution.

Understanding SAP Build Solutions

SAP Build is a comprehensive suite of low-code/no-code tools that empowers citizen developers and business users to create applications and automate processes without extensive coding knowledge. The SAP Build portfolio consists of three main components:

SAP Build Apps

  • Create and extend business applications
  • Drag-and-drop simplicity for app development
  • No coding skills required

SAP Build Process Automation

  • Create workflows and automate repetitive tasks
  • Unifies workflow management and intelligent robotic process automation
  • Streamlines business process management

SAP Build Work Zone

  • Create beautiful business websites and corporate portals
  • Centralized access to business applications and content

All these tools leverage drag-and-drop functionality, making them accessible to users without programming expertise.

Prerequisites

  • SAP BTP Trial Setup
  • Ensure that you have a SAP BTP trial account with the following services enabled:   
  • A. SAP Build Process Automation (Free Tier or Standard Plan)
    • Navigate to Service Marketplace > Search for SAP Build Process Automation
    • Click Create Application if it’s not already available.

                  

  • B. SAP Cloud Identity Services (CIS)
    • Configure IAS (Identity Authentication Service).
    • Either use the default IAS tenant of your BTP trial or configure an additional tenant or default plan if needed.        

Subscribe to SAP Build Process Automation and Cloud Identity Service into your sub-account.         

  • Role Collection Assignment in BTP Cockpit
  • Assign the following role collections to the user you’ll log in with:                 

Go to BTP Cockpit > Security > Users

Select the IAS user and assign above role collection

  1. Establish Trust with IAS
  2. Go to BTP Subaccount > Security > Trust Configuration
  3. Add a new Identity Provider if you are using a custom IAS tenant
  4.  Enable trust for that IAS and assign the user created in IAS

Step 1: Accessing SAP Build Process Automation

  1. Navigate to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Go to Services → Instances and Subscriptions
  3. Open the SAP Build Process Automation application
  4. You'll be directed to the SAP Build Lobby - the central entry point for all SAP Build tools    

Step 2: Creating a Business Process Project

  1. In the SAP Build Lobby, click the Create button
  2. Select Build an Automated Process
  3. Choose Business Process
  4. Create a new project with these details:
    • Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Form
    • Description: A invoice validation and approval process form project
  5. Click Create

The project acts as a container to hold the business process and all related artifacts.              

Step 3: Creating the Business Process

  1. Within the project, create a new business process:
    • Process Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process
    • Description: A invoice validation and approval process
  2. Click Create                  

The Process Builder will open with a vertical layout (an improvement from the previous horizontal layout) featuring a convenient side panel for better usability.

Hands-On Demo: Creating a Vendor Invoice Validation Approval Process

Let's dive into a practical example by creating a complete vendor invoice validation approval process. This demo will involve three key personas.

Business Personas Involved:

  1. Business Expert/Citizen Developer: Creates and designs the business process
  2. Finance Clerk: Uses the vendor invoice order from to initiate the process
  3. Finance Manager: Reviews and approves.rejects vendor invoice orders.

                    

Step 4: Creating the Vendor Invoice Submission Form (Trigger)

  1. Click Add a Trigger
  2. Select Submit Form (one of three trigger methods: Form, API, or Event)
  3. Click Blank Form
  4. Configure the form:
    • Form Name: Vendor Invoice Submission Form
    • Description: Form to collect vendor invoice order
  5. Click Create               

Step 5: Designing the Vendor Invoice Approval Form

  1. Click Open Editor to access the form designer
  2. Add form elements using drag-and-drop:
    • Heading: "Vendor Invoice Approval Forms"
    • Subheading: "Vendor Invoice Submission Form review by Finance Manager"
  3. Add required fields:
    • Vendor Name (Text field)
    • Invoice Number (Number field, required)
    • Invoice Date (Date field, required)
    • Vendor Email (Text field, required)
    • Invoice Amount (Number field, required)
    • Due Date (Date field, required)
  4. Mark fields as required where necessary
  5. Save the form       

Step 6: Creating the Approval Form

  1. Click Add Process Step (plus icon)
  2. Choose Approval
  3. Click Blank Approval
  4. Configure the approval form:
    • Name: Vendor Invoice Approval
    • Description: Vendor Invoice order form for review
  5. Click Create

Step 7: Designing the Approval Form

  1. Click the three dots and select Open Editor
  2. Design the form with:
    • Heading: "Sales Order Form for Review"
    • Subheading: "Sales order form for review by sales manager"
  3. Add the same fields as the trigger form:
    • Vendor Name
    • Invoice Number
    • Invoice Date
    • Vendor Email
    • Invoice Amount
    • Due Date
  4. Set all fields to Read Only (since this is for review)
  5. Add additional text field for manager comments
  6. Save the form

Step 8: Configuring the Approval Form

  1. Configure the approval settings:
    • Subject: "A Vendor Invoice [Vendor Name] form is waiting for your "
    • Priority: High
    • Users: Process started by (for simplification)
  2. Map inputs from the trigger form output:
    • Vendor Name→ Vendor Name field
    • Due Date → Due Date field
    • Invoice Number → Invoice Number field
    • Vendor Email → Vendor Email field
    • Invoice Amount → Invoice Amount field
  3. Save the configuration                     

Step 9: Creating Notification Forms

Approval Confirmation Form:

  1. Click Add Process Step → Form → Blank Form
  2. Configure:
    • Name: Vendor Invoice Order Confirmed
    • Description: Form to handle confirmation
  3. Design with:
    • Heading: "Vendor Invoice form approved successfully. No further action required."
    • Subject: "Your Vendor invoice [Vendor Name] form is confirmed!"
    • User: Process started by
  4. Save the form              

Rejection Notification Form:

  1. Go to Project Overview
  2. Duplicate the Order Confirmed form
  3. Modify the message:
    • Heading: "Invoice rejected. Please review remarks and resubmit after corrections."
    • Subject: "Your Vendor invoice [Vendor Name] has been rejected                   

Step 10: Connecting the Process Flow

  1. Connect the rejection notification to the "Rejected" path of the approval form
  2. Connect the approval confirmation to the "Approved" path
  3. Ensure both paths lead to the process end                      

Step 11: Understanding the Release Process

Why Release Before Deployment?

Before any business process can be executed by end users, it must go through two critical phases:

  1. Release: Creates a versioned snapshot of your project
  2. Deploy: Makes the released version available in runtime environment

Initiating the Release

  1. Locate the Release Button: In the top-right corner of your project interface
  2. Click Release: This opens the release configuration dialog

Release Versioning System

SAP Build Process Automation uses semantic versioning with three components:

  • Major Version (X.0.0): Significant changes, incompatible with previous versions
  • Minor Version (1.X.0): New features, backward compatible

First Release

For a newly created project, you'll see the default version 1.0.0. Add a meaningful release note such as "First release" and proceed.

Patch Changes (1.0.X)

  • Minor text modifications
  • Small UI adjustments
  • Bug fixes

Minor Changes (1.X.0)

  • New features added
  • Workflow enhancements
  • Backward-compatible improvements                       

Step 12: Deployment Process

Accessing Deployment Options

Once your project is released, the Deploy button becomes available. The deployment process involves:

  1. Click Deploy: Opens the deployment configuration
  2. Select Environment: Choose your target runtime environment

Understanding Environments

Public Environment

  • Accessible by all users in the subaccount
  • Suitable for organization-wide processes
  • Default choice for most scenarios

Deployment Execution

Select "Public" as your environment and click Deploy. You'll notice the project status changes from "Released" to "Deployed" and becomes "Active."       

Step 13: Process Execution and Testing

Accessing the Deployed Process

Once deployed, your process becomes executable through multiple channels:

  1. Direct Form Link: Browser-accessible URL
  2. SAP Build Work Zone Integration: Embedded as tiles
  3. SAP Launchpad Service: Integrated into portal environment         

Testing Scenario: Invoice Validation Approval Process Form

Phase 1: Finance Clerk Representative Role

Navigate to the deployed process and access the form link. As a finance clerk, fill out the order form:

Sample Data:

  • Vendor Name: ABCD Company
  • Invoice Number: 1234
  • Invoice Amount: $1,000
  • Due Date: 2 days from current date
  • Vendor Email : test@gmail.com
  • Invoice Date : 01/08/2025

Submit the form to initiate the workflow process.                           

Phase 2: Finance Manager Approval

  1. Access Inbox: Navigate to SAP Build Lobby > My Inbox
  2. Review Submission: Examine the submitted order details
  3. Make Decision: Choose to approve or reject based on business criteria

In our example:

  • Vendor Name: ABCD Company
  • Invoice Number: 1234
  • Invoice Amount: $1,000
  • Due Date: 2 days from current date
  • Vendor Email : test@gmail.com
  • Invoice Date : 01/08/2025

Decision: Approved with comment "This order can be fulfilled"      

Phase 3: Confirmation Process

After manager approval:

  1. Automatic Notification: System sends confirmation to finance representative
  2. Representative Action: Acknowledges receipt of approval
  3. Process Completion: Workflow concludes successfully

                        

Step 14: Process Monitoring and Analytics

Accessing Monitoring Tools

Process administrators can monitor workflow performance through: Path: SAP Build Lobby > Monitoring > Process and Workflow Instances

Key Monitoring Features

Process Instance Overview

  • Start time and initiator
  • Current status (Running, Completed, Failed)
  • Environment and version information
  • Instance ID for tracking

                     

Conclusion

SAP Build Process Automation is transforming the way organizations approach workflow digitisation by placing powerful automation tools directly in the hands of business users. As Demonstrated in our Invoice Validation Approval Process scenario, even non-technical users - like functional consultants or business experts - can quickly build, configure and deploy intelligent workflow using drag-and-drop interfaces, without writing code.  

From creating triggers  forms and configure approval steps to sending dynamic notifications, SBPA provides all the essential building blocks to automate repetitive tasks and improve collaboration across roles. Its tight integration within the SAP BTP and its ectensibility with tools like SAP Build Apps make it to go-to solutions.

By empowering citizen developer, SBPA not only reduces IT backlogs but also fosters a culture of innovations and continous improvement across teams. Now is the time to explore your business landscape, identify time-consuming manual process and turn them into streamlined intelligent workflows that deliver  measurable business value.

entry.title: Automation project cannot run with desktop agent
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I was creating an automation project in build process automation according to docu:

process-automation-enablement/Workshops/Workshop A - short/1 The Basics at main · SAP-samples/process-automation-enablement · GitHub 

Everything worked for me. When triggering the automation manually the Desktop agent runs the automation. When releasing the projekt and submitting my form, the automation gets stuck in this state and doesnt trigger the Agent to run in.

There is no error msg. Just stuck in this state for a day now

In my environment i registered my agent and added a custom attribute

Attribute is also added to my Project.

 

The Agent is installed on my local computer and has latest version. its in Unattended Mode, so it should register new projects.

This is my process:

this is the automation:

Greetings

Rouven

entry.title: Questions on Certification Exam for "SAP Certified Professional - Solution Architect - SAP BTP"
entry.content:
Hi There

I have a couple of questions regarding the Certification Exam for "SAP Certified Professional - Solution Architect - SAP BTP" which is available in this link - https://learning.sap.com/certifications/sap-certified-professional-solution-architect-sap-btp

Question-1: Does this exam have any additional requirements apart from theoretical questions? I am asking this because this exam is named "Professional" instead of "Associate"

Question-2: In the above link under the section "Topics covered in this exam", I can only see "Exam percentage > 50%". What about the remaining percentage? Where can I get the list of topics for the remaining percentage?

Best Regards, Arul

entry.content:

entry.title: I NEED HELP IN RESOLVING ERROR IN ECLIPSE
entry.content:
" An error occurred during the org.eclipse.equinox.internal.p2.engine.phases.CheckTrust phase.

session context was:(profile=C__Users_USER-PC_eclipse_java-2025-06_eclipse, phase=org.eclipse.equinox.internal.p2.engine.phases.CheckTrust, operand=, action=).

Error reading signed content.

invalid distance too far back "

 

The message above in quote is the error message I received when trying to install ABAP ADT on Eclipse (with the link: https://tools.hana.ondemand.com/latest ). Please I need guidance on how to resolve this issue. Thank you

entry.title: Is the "SAP Certified Associate - SAP Generative AI Developer" certification a solid entry point?
entry.content:
Hi everyone,

I saw that SAP recently released the SAP Certified Associate - SAP Generative AI Developer certification. I’m currently exploring how to get started with AI from a technical perspective, and this certification caught my attention. I’m curious to know if it could be a practical and valuable entry point.

Here’s what I’m looking for:

  • Feedback from anyone who has taken or started preparing for this certification.
  • Whether the developer tools, frameworks, and APIs related to SAP’s Generative AI are production-ready or still evolving.
  • Your thoughts on whether this certification will hold value from a technical and practical perspective over the next few years.

I’m absolutely fine if the offering is still maturing, I just want to avoid diving in too early if it’s not yet relevant for developers.

Looking forward to hearing your thoughts and experiences!

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: SAP Build Process Automation: Process Triggers: A Step-by-Step Demo on Invoice Validation Approval
entry.content:
Disclaimer: The insights shared in this blog are based on my personal observations and learning. They may not apply universally, and I encourage readers to conduct their own research and make an informed decision before using this content for productive use.

Welcome back to our SAP Build Process Automation series! In this second blog, we'll dive deep into one of the most crucial aspects of process automation: how to trigger your business processes. Understanding the various trigger mechanisms is essential for building robust, automated workflows that can respond to different business scenarios.

Every business process follows a simple flow: it starts with a trigger, executes a series of activities, and ends with a desired outcome. The question is: how do we initiate these processes effectively? Today, we'll explore the four primary ways to trigger processes in SAP Build Process Automation with complete step-by-step instructions.

API Triggers

Let's walk through a comprehensive implementation of API triggers using our Sales Order Management example.

Prerequisites

Before starting, ensure you have:

  1. Access to SAP Build Process Automation
  2. A working process (we'll use the vendor invoice validation approval process project from previous episodes)
  3. Any Rest Client software (web or desktop version)
  4. BTP Cockpit access for service key retrieval - trial cockpit

Step-by-Step Implementation 

Phase 1: Project Setup and Preparation 

Step 1: Create a Copy of Your Existing Project from previous blog

  1. Navigate to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Locate your existing project (e.g., "Invoice Validation Approval Process Form")
  3. Select the project by clicking on it
  4. Click "Save As" to create a copy
  5. Enter new project details: 
    1. Project Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Trigger 
    2. Description: A invoice validation and approval process trigger
  6. Click "Save" to create the new project   

Step 2: Access and Prepare the Process

  1. Open the newly created project
  2. Navigate to the process section
  3. You should see:
    • Four forms
    • One process
    •  Existing form trigger (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)

Phase 2: Removing Existing Process and Adding API Trigger

Step 3: Remove the Existing Form Process

  1. Click on the existing form process (Invoice Validation Approval Process Form)
  2. Click "Remove" to delete the form
  3. You'll now see a block asking "How do you want to start your process?"
  4. Click "Add a trigger"

Step 4: Explore Available Trigger Options You'll see four trigger options:

  1. Submit a form: Creates/uses existing forms
  2. API trigger: For external system integration
  3. Event trigger: For event-driven processes
  4. Schedule trigger: For time-based execution

Step 5: Create the API Trigger

  1. Click on "API Trigger"
  2. Save the process (mandatory before creating API trigger)
    • Click the Save button
  3. Configure API Trigger Details: 
    • Name: Invoice Validation Approval Process Trigger 
    • Identifier: [Auto-generated - do not modify]
  4. Click "Create"
  5. You'll see a success message: "API trigger created successfully"   

Phase 3: Understanding API Trigger Configuration 

Step 6: Examine API Trigger Properties

  1. Click on the API trigger you just created
  2. Review Output Fields:
  • These are automatically synchronized from process inputs
  • Fields include: Vendor Name, Invoice Number, Invoice Date, Vendor Email, Invoice Amount, Due Date
  • These represent the data structure your API will receive

Step 7: Check Process Variables Synchronization

  1. Click anywhere in the process canvas
  2. Navigate to Variables tab
  3. Select "Process Inputs"
  4. Verify synchronization:
    • API trigger outputs = Process inputs
    • This ensures seamless data flow

Step 8: Review API Configuration Details

  1. Click on the API trigger
  2. Go to "Configuration" tab
  3. Note the important details:
    • Field Identifiers: Use these in JSON (not display names)
    • Mandatory Fields: All fields shown are required
    • Data Types: Note numeric vs. string vs. date formats

Phase 4: Project Release and Deployment 

Step 9: Release the Project

  1. Save all changes
  2. Click "Release" button in the top toolbar
  3. Confirm the release when prompted
  4. Wait for successful release message

Step 10: Deploy the Project

  1. Click "Deploy" button (appears after release)
  2. Select target environment (typically "Public Environment")
  3. Confirm deployment
  4. Wait for deployment completion
  5. Note the deployment success message

Phase 5: Accessing Deployment Information 

Step 11: Navigate to Control Tower

  1. Go to SAP Build Lobby home
  2. Click on "Control Tower"
  3. Navigate to "Tenant Configuration"
  4. Click on "Environments"
  5. Select "Public Environment" (or your deployment target)

Step 12: Locate Your Deployed Project

  1. Find your project: "Vendor Invoice Validation Approval Process Triggers"
  2. Click on the project name
  3. Navigate to "Triggers" tab
  4. Locate: "Vendor Invoice Approval API Trigger"

Step 13: Get API Endpoint Information

  1. Click on "View Trigger"
  2. Copy the API URL - you'll need this for Rest Client
  3. Review the Payload Definition - this shows the exact JSON structure required

Example URL Structure:  https://[Tenant-URL] /workflow/rest/v1/workflow-instances

Example Payload Structure JSON: 

{  
"definitionId": "[auto-generated-id]", 
"context": {  
"Vendor Name": "string",  
"invoiceNumber": "number",  
"invoiceDate": "date", 
"vendorEmail": "string", 
"invoiceAmount": "number",  
"dueDate": "date"  
} 
} 

Phase 6: BTP Service Key Configuration 

Step 14: Access BTP Cockpit

  1. Open BTP Cockpit in a new tab
  2. Navigate to your subaccount
  3. Go to "Instances and Subscriptions"
  4. Locate "SAP Build Process Automation"

Step 15: Retrieve Service Key Details

  1. Click on "SAP Build Process Automation" service
  2. Navigate to "Service Keys" tab
  3. Click on existing service key (or create one if none exists)
  4. Copy the following values: 
{  
"endpoints": {    
"api": "[API_ENDPOINT]"  
},  
"uaa": {    
"clientid ": "[CLIENT_ID]",    
"clientsecret": "[CLIENT_SECRET]",    
"url": "[TOKEN_URL]"  
} 
}

Phase 7: Rest Client Configuration and Testing 

Step 16: Configure OAuth 2.0 Authentication

  1. Go to "Authorization" tab
  2. Select "OAuth 2.0" from dropdown
  3. Configure OAuth settings:
    • Token Name: SAP Build Token (or any name)
    • Grant Type: Client Credentials
    • Access Token URL: [TOKEN_URL from service key]
    • Client ID: [CLIENT_ID from service key]
    • Client Secret: [CLIENT_SECRET from service key]

Step 17: Generate Access Token

  1. Click "Get New Access Token"
  2. Wait for token generation
  3. Click "Use Token" when generated
  4. Verify: You should see "Authentication complete" message

Step 18: Configure Request Body

  1. Go to "Body" tab
  2. Select "raw"
  3. Select "JSON" from dropdown
  4. Enter the payload: 
{
"definitionId": "[DEFINITION_ID_from_step_13]",
"context": {  
"vendorName": "ABCD",
"invoiceNumber": 1234,
"invoiceDate": "2025-08-05",
"vendorEmail": "abcd@test.com",
"invoiceAmount": 1000,
"dueDate": "2025-08-08" 
}
}

Step 19: Execute the API Call

  1. Click "Send"
  2. Expected Response:     
{
  "status": "201 Created",
  "message": "New resource was created successfully"
}

Phase 8: Process Monitoring and Verification 
Step 21: Monitor Process Instance

  1. Return to SAP Build Lobby
  2. Navigate to "Monitoring"
  3. Click "Process and Workflow Instances"
  4. Locate your new process instance:
    • Status: Running
    • Instance ID: [Auto-generated]
    • Started by: API Trigger

Step 22: Review Process Data

  1. Click on the process instance
  2. Review "Process Details":
    • Vendor Name: ABCD
    • Invoice Number: 1234
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Vendor Email: abcd@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-08

    3. Check process flow: Should be waiting for approval

Phase 9: Complete the Approval Workflow 

Step 23: Access Manager Inbox

  1. Navigate to "My Inbox" app
  2. Login as Finance Clerk
  3. Locate the approval task:
    • Title: Vendor Name [ABCD]
    • Status: Open
    • All order details visible

Step 24: Process the Approval

  1. Click on the task
  2. Review order details:
    • Vendor Name: ABCD
    • Invoice Amount: 1000
    • Invoice Email: abcd@test.com
    • Due Date: 2024-08-08
    • Invoice Number - 1234
    • Invoice Date - 2024-08-05
  3. Add approval comment:
  4. Click "Approve"
  5. Confirm: "Task has been processed successfully"

Step 25: Handle Vendor Invoice Representative Notification

  1. Switch to Finance Manager role
  2. Check "My Inbox"
  3. Locate notification: "Vendor Invoice form approved successfully"
  4. Click on notification
  5. Review confirmation details
  6. Click "Submit"

Step 26: Verify Process Completion

  1. Return to "Process and Workflow Instances"
  2. Refresh the page
  3. Check your process instance:
    • Status: Completed
    • All approval messages visible
    • Complete process flow executed  

Conclusion

In this blog, we walked through the complete lifecycle of implementing API triggers in SAP Build Process Automation using a real-world scenario of vendor invoice validation and approval. From project setup to deployment, from obtaining service keys to testing API calls with Rest Client, we demonstrated how API triggers enable seamless integration between external systems and your automated workflows.

This approach empowers businesses to respond programmatically to events, ensuring faster and more scalable process initiation. Whether you're integrating SAP Build with external applications, triggering approvals based on backend systems, or building custom UI workflows, API triggers provide the flexibility and control needed for robust automation.

entry.title: Not able to fetch routing args in onRouteMatched() from semantic object and navigation from Workzone
entry.content:
Greeting Experts,

I am trying to develop UI5 app where First page routing parameter will come from SAP Build Work zone, standard edition application navigation parameters. But when I am defining route patterns in manifest.json file for first page It is showing blank on output screen. Here is code for manifest.json.

 "routes": [
        {
          "name": "RouteDashboard",
          "pattern": "Employee/{role}",
          "target": [
            "TargetDashboard"
          ]
        }

  In workzone, standard edition I am giving navigation parameters like this.                                                           

Dashboard controller:- 

Can anybody help me on this, while passing parameter in manifest file I am not able to see anything and if I remove this I can see the output of app but can't fetch argument from onRouteMatched in this case. Any help would be appreciated.

Example before:

Example afterwards:

entry.title: To set up a destination in SAP BTP for connecting to the Microsoft Azure Mail Service -Graph API
entry.content:
1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit 

  • Log into SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to SAP BTP Cockpit 
  • Navigate to Subaccount: In the subaccount of your choice (where the destination will be configured), click on the subaccount to access its settings.

2. Create a New Destination

  • Navigate to Destinations:

    • In the SAP BTP Cockpit, go to Connectivity > Destinations (under the Connectivity section in your subaccount).

    • Create New Destination:

      • Click + (Create New Destination).

      • Fill in the following fields:

3. Configure the Destination for Microsoft Graph API

     Fill in the required fields to define the destination for Microsoft Graph API:

     General Information

  • Name: Choose a descriptive name for the destination, e.g., AzureMailService.

  • Type: Select HTTP.

  • Description: Provide a brief description, e.g., "Destination for Microsoft Graph API to send transactional emails."

  • URL:  https://graph.microsoft.com/V1.0

4. Authentication Settings

  • Authentication:

    • Select OAuth2 for OAuth authentication, since Microsoft Graph API requires OAuth2 Client Credentials flow.

    • OAuth2 Client Credentials: This will be your method for obtaining access tokens to authenticate API requests.

      • OAuth2 Client ID: This is the Client ID from the Azure AD app you registered in the Azure portal.

      • OAuth2 Client Secret: This is the Client Secret generated for the Azure AD app.

      • OAuth2 Token URL: The token URL from Microsoft Identity Platform, which is:

         
        https://login.microsoftonline.com/{tenantId}/oauth2/v2.0/token

        Replace {tenantId} with your actual tenant ID.

      • OAuth2 Scope: For sending emails, use the scope Mail.Send. This allows the app to send emails through Microsoft Graph API.

      • OAuth2 Grant Type: Choose Client Credentials as you're using the client credentials flow.

5.Connection Settings

  • URL: Set the URL to connect to Microsoft Graph API. The base URL for Microsoft Graph is:

     
    https://graph.microsoft.com

  • Proxy Type: If you are using a proxy, you can set it here. If not, leave it as None.

  • Additional Headers: You can add any extra headers if needed. Usually, for Microsoft Graph API, no additional headers are required apart from the authorization header, which is handled automatically by the OAuth2 configuration.

6. Test the Destination

  • Test Connectivity: After creating the destination, test it by clicking on Check Connection.

  • Successful Connection: If the connection is successful, you’ll see a message confirming that the destination is reachable.

7. Secure the Destination

  • Security Considerations:

    • Make sure that only authorized users and applications have access to this destination.

    • You can use Role-Based Access Control (RBAC) to limit who can access this destination in SAP BTP.

8. Integrate the Destination into Your Application

Once the destination is configured, you can integrate it into your Node.js or CAPM application to use it for sending emails.

  • Access Destination Programmatically:

    const { retrieveJwt } = require('@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity');
    const { executeHttpRequest } = require('@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client');
    module.exports = srv => {
      srv.on('sendmail', async (req) => {
            const JWT_Token = retrieveJwt(req);    // Access the destination via JWT Secured token
        const destination = {
          destinationName: 'AzureMailService', JWT_Token
         };
      }
    }

Use Destination in API Requests: Use the executeHttpRequest method from the SAP Cloud SDK to make requests to the Microsoft Graph API, passing in the destination to authenticate the request.

Conclusion

By setting up a destination for the Microsoft Azure Mail Service in SAP BTP, you establish a secure and centralized way for your SAP applications to send transactional emails via the Microsoft Graph API. This eliminates the need for third-party email services, reduces costs, and ensures a reliable and scalable email service across your BTP landscape.

entry.title: Customizing Extraction Fields in SAP Document Information Extraction (DOX)
entry.content:
Hello, 

I’m currently evaluating SAP Document Information Extraction (DOX) in SAP Document AI using a trial account. Although I’ve noticed that it extracts every text very accurately, not every text is being mapped to the extraction fields.
 
I wanted to add/customize header fields myself to map the extracted text to header fields or line items better (while following this link https://help.sap.com/docs/document-ai/sap-document-ai/add-data-fields to add data fields) but schema configuration doesn’t appear in my trial environment. It also states that I cannot change SAP schemas as shown in the attached image below:

So I was wondering if it's possible to edit/customize extraction fields in the premium version of SAP Document AI? If so, does this customization occur before the optical character recognition (OCR) to guide the model, or only after OCR to map extracted text to fields?
 
Defining custom field mappings before OCR would be extremely valuable for my team's use case, so I’d greatly appreciate if anyone can explain what’s possible before I consider upgrading to a full subscription. Thank you.

entry.title: BTP B2B Monitoring Alert Email
entry.content:
Hello Experts
 
We've recently implemented B2B trading partner management and begun using CPI for EDI. We've found that monitoring can be challenging, and we're working on a solution that automatically triggers an email to our EDI email address whenever an error appears on our monitoring dashboard.
 
We've already activated the Alert Notification service, but we'd appreciate your guidance on how to fulfill this specific requirement.
 
Thanks & regards
Abhishek Raikwar
